title: Can We Discuss What Is Ruining Game Experience
body:
So I've been playing this game for over 4 years. New accounts, trying things out, picking off meta, trolling sometimes, picking braindead champions, picking meta champions, going Jarvan Camille botlane and dominating, and there is one thing I've noticed. 

Every single game has somebody who doesn't care, win or lose, they remember its just a game. Then there are 2 people who care, but not enough to afk over a bad support pick. Then there are 2 people who either troll, type way to much, or get passive toxic in game. 

And you know what, i want this to change, almost all players do. Nothing is going to change these things however. 

But here is an idea.

Every time a player logs in, present them with their chat logs, ALL OF THEM, from the last time they logged in. Have these appear on screen, and don't allow the player to remove them or start a game until maybe 2-3 minutes go by. Many people are only toxic sometimes, or rarely, but some circumstances in game can bring it out. Maybe after seeing the things they've said, they can reform themselves before it gets too far. 

Players getting out of hand ruins the game, toxic or whatever many players don't care about. Showing somebody the sheer amount of messages they've typed over a few games can be an eye opener to many players.

This tries to address a really deep philosophical question: Is it the role of a game (or in the past, governments, etc) to change the behavior of the individual? Or is it up to the individual and communities they inhabit to identify their need for change and adjust themselves. 

To be clear, not offering any opinion either way, just highlighting a fundamental base problem that human kind has been addressing for ages :)

The reality of the situation is that a toxic community will turn away non-toxic players and only become worse on its own, eventually making the game unplayable. The philosophical discussion of responsibility is irrelevant when the utilitarian discussion of reality clearly shows there's one path to watching the game slowly die and another path to keeping it sustainable.

I genuinely believe it is the game's job. Rampant toxicity in a competitive game is just a corruption that breeds itself and replicates with no real end. Players do NOT have the tools to adjust themselves in a video game so I don't think the philosophy is applicable. All I can do in a video game is say "hey friend, please don't mean, we can win". If we want players to control themselves then I believe riot should bring back the tribunal and literally let us do that. Let the community through the tribunal decide what is acceptable levels of toxicity.

I don't think it is really all that deep.  We aren't talking about human rights we are talking about game experience.  Riot doesn't need to change any persons behavior, but they need to enforce rules and proactively seek solutions to problems that will make the game experience better for everyone.   

Riot should take the role of the NFL or NBA and establish and enforce rules that promote the game and make the game have a fun and competitive and fair (for ranked) environment.  

What happened with the NBA in 2005 is a great example of what needs to happen to League, especially when considering ranked game play.  In 2004 there was a very poor perception and reality of the NBA.  There was prevalent use of drugs and violence, a culture that culminated with the "Malice at the Palace" incident.  After this, in 2005 the NBA and David Stern overhauled the league security regarding players and fans as well, going as far as reducing alcohol consumption in stadiums and enforcing a dress-code on the players.  This fundamentally changed the NBA and if the players wanted to still play, they needed to adapt to the system.  

Playing LOL is a privileged, not a right.

I agree that Riot should take a more strict and proactive stance. But how can you say that "enforcing rules and proactively seek solutions" is not "change players behavior"? Of course it is? The *goal* of these rules and solutions, the very reason they exist IS to change players behavior.

To elaborate, the goal would be to create a enjoyable game environment etc.  This does not require players to change their behavior, they can still have the same attitudes, they just won't be allowed to play the game.  If the result is that they change their behavior then great, if not, I don't care, because they are out of the game.  

This might be semantics a little bit, I see your point, but the goal here is important.  The goal of an enjoyable game environment etc, can be achieved without changing behavior.  This is important because as we have seen over many years, many games, if you just leave it up to people to be nice to each other in these spaces, it doesn't happen.

I think an idea like this is a combination of both, with the game providing a means for a player to look and self-reform should they choose to. I would personally love to see my chat logs and see how i can be in game. I don't think there is a way to do this however ;(

> 
> To be clear, not offering any opinion either way, just highlighting a fundamental base problem that human kind has been addressing for ages :)

The fundamental assumption is false. All games, governments, rules, laws are created by individuals. There is no such thing as a "game" or "government" that is in itself an entity. The second assumption explains the first, but the first assumption is nothing but the arbitrary conceptualization of the second.

It also is an opportunity to point out: The world is filled with mental disabilities, challenges that make people socially inept, and incapable of change due to genetics, not learned behavior, and no automated system can discern between them.

A lot of the people Riot bans are simply Autistic, ADHD, Bipolar, or have a wide spectrum of mental disorders.

So while you're trying to answer philosophical questions about whether to help a reform process, or to have the reformer help themselves, you're completely ignoring the first order question of..... should you in the first place?

We are products of our DNA and our parent's lessons first. Our ability to change who we are is limited. Only within a tiny margin are people capable of truly changing, and that margin even deteriorates as we Age. If you are older than 27 years old, your brain is generally fully mature, and you are going to lose flexibility from that point on. After 27, you generally only learn through retention, and to process new information. Your emotional build is done. You either are socially neurotypical and acceptable, or you aren't (within a margin).
----------------------------------------------------
But how do you factor this into behavioral modification (punishment or otherwise), and have your cake too?

Well..... The dual endeavors of trying to keep up with competitive player skill curves while trying to keep a clean environment conflict with each other.

I understand very well why Riot keeps making champion kits more flexible, more available, and gold incomes up: Players have become so much better on the average that mechanically, they are taking the old kits, and making them incompatible with their pace of reaction. So, we're driving toward minimal reaction time play.

But, the more Riot adapts the game to learning curves and reducing reaction times, there are always more laggards (players who either have an inability to adapt, or players who adapt slower than the rate at which your baseline competitive player is.

Players don't interpret the data on a macro level that comes from these laggard interactions. They just see "inting," situations where they knew exactly what would happen, but their teammates did it anyways, and have seen enough games over time to generally predict a game's outcome by 8-9 minutes. While the inting may have actually just been a skill curve laggard being unable to react to a good player, all their team sees is inting. Or, when you know with a 100% Certainty, that a play will be successful if your teammate does anything more than "breathe," and your teammate doesn't even do that, you generally see an ineptitude where in reality, they could have just been doing the risk math different, and only trusting themselves, and not you.

Bottom line: _**The more Riot focuses on the .5 second play window, and creating those dynamics, the worse the community will behave. The only way to combat an increase in bad behavior, ironically, is to bring the game back to a state where pro players are not the baseline, but rather get away with being "Godlike" while lower tier players are given more time to react. Bring the game back to 1-2 second reaction time capacity, and toxicity will go down, because people on average will perform better.**_

In my humble, but firm, opinion, yes it is.

Humans as individuals are notably bad at a number of things, but one of our biggest strength is the ability to build systems around us that compensate those bad sides and incentivize us to behave better than when left to our own device. I don't want to fall into biologic essentialism, but it's """natural""" that individuals behave badly, it is to be expected, and we have to make sure the system around them (in this case: the game) pushes them in the right direction.

Time is one of league's big selling points, compared to a lot of games league can be a rather short investment, with arams taking around 20 minutes start to finish. Adding an extra 2-3 minutes is huge here. This doesn't even begin to address why showing someone what they wrote through force is a bad way to change people's actions. Honestly the fact that you believe this would have any merit makes me think you are probably very naive when it comes to how people work.

I've said it before and I'll say it again, the ONLY way to improve player behavior (that is controllable) is to modify ranked so that individual play is at least HALF your LP gain/loss determinant.  Toxicity is lower (not non-existent, but lower) in normals because most people "don't care".  I want to win, but if things go south, you don't get too worked up because it doesn't "mean" anything.  Ranked is a cesspool because whether INTENTIONAL (trolls & smurfs) or unintentional (just weak), players make each other frustrated because 4 TOTALLY RANDOM people determine whether you advance or not, and when one (or more) of them have an outsized impact on your results, it is incredibly annoying.  If they're doing it intentionally, they'll often TRY to goad you into toxicity with taunts and frustrating plays, and if they're doing it unintentionally, then you will often push THEM into toxicity when your frustration gets the best of you.

And that's all it is, is pent-up, continually building FRUSTRATION.  When you work with customers, its not usually a problem that one person is an idiot, it's that you deal with a thousand customers and if 10% of them are idiots then you see 100 idiots and after you pass 50, you just don't want to deal with them anymore.

Just have the chat logs scroll on a loop while the player is queuing. Most players won't be bothered seeing their own chat for a second or two before they alt-tab out to their time waster.
But for the section of the community that get way too heated, that say things in chat that they would never say in a calm state of mind, being confronted with their own toxicity will cause them to feel embarrassment.
They will, of course, just alt-tab out and try to put it out of their minds. But they'll be reminded every time they queue up. Even if they get real good at alt-tabbing out right away, the very act of doing so will bring to mind that which they desperately want to ignore.
This will cause them to consciously work toward keeping their cool, to avoid their own disapproval.
